items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Today is forecast to be mainly dry but more rain is forecast tomorrow morning, 29/10/21. 
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Water levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses as a result of persistent heavy rain. Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land in locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near these watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. The level of the lake is expected to remain above this flood alert threshold into the coming weekend. We are monitoring the situation and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated later today 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ehen, Rive Calder, River Irt, River Esk

items.message: River levels remain steady but high at the Egremont river gauge as a result of the persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Ennerdale Bridge, Cleator Moor, Cleator, Egremont, Beckermet, Braystones, Calder Bridge, Holmrook and Bootle areas. High river levels remain possible on the River Wyre, Distington Beck, Pow Beck, River Ehen, River Keekle, Skirting Beck, Whangs Beck, Kirk Beck, River Calder, River Irt, River Esk, River Annas and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking and clearing debris screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Greta, St Johns Beck and Bassenthwaite Lake

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Greta, St Johns Beck, Glendermackin

items.message: River levels will remain high at the Keswick Camp Site river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. The areas we expect to be affected are the Mungrisdale, Threlkeld, Keswick, Portinscale, Braithwaite, Bassenthwaite and Wythop Mill areas. River and lake levels will remain high on the River Glenderamackin, St Johns Beck, River Greta, Naddle Beck, Cuddy Beck, River Derwent, Newlands Beck, Coledale Beck, Bassenthwaite Lake, Halls Beck, Chapel Beck, Wythop Beck and their tributaries. With rainfall easing overnight tonight (28/10/21) levels will remain steady but high throughout Friday and into the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels remain steady but high at the Egremont river gauge as a result of the persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Ennerdale Bridge, Cleator Moor, Cleator, Egremont, Beckermet, Braystones, Calder Bridge, Holmrook and Bootle areas. High river levels remain on the River Wyre, Distington Beck, Pow Beck, River Ehen, River Keekle, Skirting Beck, Whangs Beck, Kirk Beck, River Calder, River Irt, River Esk, River Annas and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking and clearing debris screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain stable but high on the Rivers Wampool and Ellen due to the heavy rainfall. Flooding will continue to affect locations near the Rivers Wampool and Ellen, with low lying land expected to be most affected. Other watercourses from Dalston to Maryport also remain affected (including low lying areas around Wigton, Abbeytown, Silloth, Allonby, Aspatria and Dearham). We will continue to monitor levels closely and our staff are out clearing blockages. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message: River levels will remain high and steady on the Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent due to the persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding to low lying land and roads remain. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Buttermere, Lorton Valley, Cockermouth, Branthwaite, Bridgefoot, Camerton, Barepot and Workington areas. High river levels will remain on the River Cocker, Whit Beck, River Derwent, River Marron, Lostrigg Beck and their tributaries. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Mint Bridge and Victoria Bridge river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. With rainfall easing overnight tonight (28/10/21), river levels are expected to remain steady but high until tomorrow (29/10/21). Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Staveley, Ings, Burneside, Kendal, Garnett Bridge, Stainton, Sedgwick, Holme, Beetham and Milnthorpe areas. High river levels are possible on the Rivers Kent, Gowan, Sprint, Mint, Stock Beck, Stainton Beck, Peasey Beck, Farleton Beck, River Bela, Holme Beck and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation and our teams are out checking defences and debris screens. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/21 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain stable but high on the Rivers Esk and Irthing due to the persistent rainfall. Flooding will continue to affect locations near the Rivers Esk and Irthing, with low lying land expected to be most affected, including low lying areas around Longtown and Brampton. We are clearing debris from screens in the area and will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain stable but high on the Rivers Lowther and Eamont due to persistent heavy rainfall. Flooding will continue to affect locations near the Rivers Lowther and Eamont, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Eamont and Lowther to their confluence with the River Eden at Langwathby. We are monitoring the situation and our staff have been checking defences and unblocking debris screens where needed. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: Water levels remain high on Lake Windermere, Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, particularly from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands which includes low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel due to the recent persistent rainfall. With rainfall easing overnight tonight (28/10/21) levels will remain steady but high. We are monitoring the situation and our staff have been checking defences and unblocking debris screens where needed. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rothay at Grasmere, White Bridge and Stock Lane

items.message: The level of Derwent Water remains high following recent heavy rainfall. With showers forecast for the next few days lake levels are forecast to fall slowly. Areas at risk of flooding include low lying land bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This Flood Warning is expected to remain in place for several days as the levels will remain high. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message by 5:00 pm today the 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain stable but high at the Linstock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Crosby-on-Eden, Linstock, Carlisle and Rockcliffe areas. High river levels remain on the River Eden, River Caldew, River Petteril, Durranhill Beck, Brunstock Beck, Gosling Sike, Little Caldew, Parham Beck, Rockcliffe Beck and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are checking rivers for blockages. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Greta at Keswick, Keswick Campsite, Rugby Club and Quinta
items.message: Whilst river levels have peaked and rainfall has eased, river levels remain high at the Keswick Camp Site river gauge as a result of recent persistent heavy rainfall.  Further showers are forecast this morning and consequently, the risk of flooding to property, roads and farmland remains. Flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying roads, residential, commercial properties and campsites in Keswick adjacent to the Rivers Greta and Derwent. Including Greta Park Rugby Football Ground, Keswick Campsite, Keswick School Sports Field, Keswick Show Field and Playing Field areas. We continue to closely monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message by 5:00 PM today,  29/10/2021.

items.description: River Kent at Burneside, Steeles Row and Carling Steps

items.message: River levels are high on the River Lune due to heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible for the next few days. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Lune, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Lune, Rawthey and other watercourses from Tebay to Kirkby Lonsdale including Sedburgh and Killington. High river levels are likely on the River Lune, Rawthey and other watercourses from Tebay to Kirkby Lonsdale including Sedburgh and Killington. Further rainfall is forecast until Friday 29/10/2021. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the River Lune and River Conder due to rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible for the next few days. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Lune; River Conder, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Lune, Conder and Keer and other watercourses from Kirkby Lonsdale to Galgate including Gressingham, Carnforth, Hornby, Wray, Bentham and Lancaster. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the Upper River Ure is no longer in force. River levels on the Upper Ure did not rise to levels predicted because rainfall totals came in below the level forecast on Wednesday evening. Further rainfall is expected throughout today, Thursday 28th October, which may see river levels rise again. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will re-issue the flood alert if it is required. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Gilling Beck, Skeeby Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Swale is no longer in force. River levels on the Upper Swale did not rise to levels predicted because rainfall totals came in below the level forecast on Wednesday evening. Further rainfall is expected throughout today, Thursday 28th October, which may see river levels rise again. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will re-issue the flood alert if it is required. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Ehen at Egremont, Bleach Green, Ennerdale Mill, Bridge End, Vale View, Wood Bank, Rugby Club
items.message: While river levels have peaked and rainfall has eased, river levels remain high on the River Ehen due to recent persistent rainfall. River levels have been falling overnight but are forecast to rise again towards a second, lower peak around 3:00 PM this afternoon 29/10/2021.  Areas that continue to be at risk are locations near the River Ehen, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties adjacent to the River Ehen at Egremont, including the Bleach Green, Ennerdale Mill, Bridge End, Vale View, Wood Bank and Rugby Club areas. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message by 4:00 PM this afternoon, 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Whilst river levels have peaked and rainfall has eased, river levels on the River Cocker remain high due to recent persistent rainfall. River levels have been falling overnight but are forecast to rise again towards a second, lower, peak around 3:00 PM this afternoon 29/10/2021. High river levels will continue to affect locations near the River Cocker, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around farms and property adjacent the River Cocker in the Lorton Valley, Southwaite Bridge and Southwaite Mill. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message by 4:00 PM this today 29/10/2021.

items.description: Rivers Cocker and Derwent at Cockermouth, Cricket Ground and Trout Hotel Car Park
items.message: Whilst river levels have peaked and rainfall has eased, river levels remain high on the Rivers Cocker and Derwent due to recent persistent heavy rainfall. Areas that remain most at risk include commercial and residential properties adjacent to the Rivers Cocker and Derwent at Cockermouth, in the Brewery Lane, Bridge Street, Crown Street, High Sand Lane, Main Street and Waterloo Street areas. Whilst river levels remain high we will keep all flood gates closed in the area and will continue to monitor. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will update this message by 04:00 PM today 29/10/21.

items.description: River Derwent at Workington, Seaton Mill and Barepot
items.message: Whilst river levels have peaked and rainfall has eased, river levels remain high on the River Derwent due to recent heavy rainfall. Areas that continue to be at risk include residential and commercial properties at Seaton Mill, Barepot, Hall Park, Hall Park View, Workington Police Station, Leisure Centre, Bowling Green and Cricket Club. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message by 5:00 PM today 29/10/2021.

items.description: River Leven at Newby Bridge and Backbarrow
items.message: River levels remain high following prolonged rainfall and some further rain is forecast for today, Friday 29/10/21.Flooding is expected at properties adjacent to the River Leven at Newby Bridge and Backbarrow, including the Swan Hotel, Boat Houses, Mill Farm, The Whitewater Hotel, Water Close, Lakeland Village, Coach House and Levens Dale. We continue to closely monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message this afternoon by 16:00 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high following prolonged rainfall, and as a consequence, Windermere Lake levels continue to rise slowly. Flooding is expected to remain a risk to low lying commercial and residential properties, camping, caravan sites and leisure facilities on the shores of Windermere today Friday 29/10/21. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will update this message this afternoon by 16:00 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Marchington Brook, Picknall Brook, Rolleston Brook

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight Thursday and in to Friday morning.

Heavy rain is forecast to fall in the Rivers Clyst and Culm area until Friday morning. This will cause water levels in the Rivers Clyst, Culm and their tributaries to rise. 

Flooding is possible to low lying land and roads close to the rivers from Thursday evening. 

We expect the rivers to remain high throughout Friday though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not currently expected to be issued.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning.
Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall in the River Dart area until early Friday morning. This will cause water levels in the River Dart to rise. 
Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised riverside field flooding from 8:30pm on Thursday. 
We expect the river to remain high throughout Friday with further rainfall expected from Friday evening.  
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Plym, Tory Brook, Long Brook

items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening, Thursday 28th October, and into Friday due to persistent and heavy rainfall crossing the area. Following unsettled weather over the past week, catchments are saturated and rivers are likely to respond quickly to the forecast rainfall.
Widespread rainfall totals of 20-30 mm are expected. Intense rain may result in totals of up 50 mm, increasing to 70mm over high ground. This may result in deep surface water and flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers from around 8pm on Thursday. Flood warnings may be issued for some locations.
The most persistent rain is expected to ease during Friday before further outbreaks of rain spread in from the west during the evening and into Saturday. River levels are likely to remain high during this time.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area ready to clear blockages as required. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are still rising on the River Tweed at the Norham gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall today, 28/10/21. Consequently, flooding of riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads between Carham to Union Bridge is possible this evening and into the early hours of Friday morning (29/10/21) when river levels are expected to peak. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Coly, River Yarty, Umborne Brook

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning. 
Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall over mid and east Devon until early Friday morning.
The River Axe, River Coly, Umborne Brook and River Yarty are likely to rise to bankfull conditions with some localised riverside flooding.   
Further rain is forecast from Friday evening into Saturday morning. This will cause river levels to rise again with further flooding expected in the area.  
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall in the River Teign area until early Friday morning. This will cause water levels in the River Teign and its tributaries to rise. 
Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised riverside field flooding from 6:45pm on Thursday. 
We expect the rivers to remain high throughout Friday with further rainfall expected from Friday evening.  
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes

items.description: Rivers Otter and Sid, and Exmouth area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning. 
Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall over mid and east Devon until early Friday morning. 
This has meant that the River Otter, the River Sid, and rivers in the Exmouth area are now rising. River levels will remain high and flooding to low lying land and roads is likely.   
Further rain is forecast from Friday evening into Saturday morning. This will cause river levels to rise again with further flooding expected in the area.  
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight on Thursday and into Friday morning.
Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall in the River Torridge area until early Friday morning. This has meant that the River Torridge is now rising. 
Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land including car parking areas and roads close to the river from around 3:30am on Friday morning. Residents may need to install flood boards to prevent wash generated from cars from entering properties.  
Further rain is forecast overnight on Friday. This will cause river levels to rise again with further flooding expected in the area.  
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Exe, River Batherm, River Lowman, River Haddeo

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight Thursday and in to Friday morning.

Heavy rain is forecast to fall in the River Exe area until Friday morning. This will cause water levels in the Rivers Exe, Haddeo, Batherm and Lowman to rise. 

The main area of concern is at Bampton, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river and around the bridge from the early hours of Friday morning. 

We expect rivers to remain high throughout Friday though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not currently expected to be issued.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning.

Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall in the South Devon Rivers area until early Friday morning. This will cause water levels in the Rivers Harbourne, Avon and Erme to rise.

Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised riverside field flooding around Crowdy Mill from 2am on Friday.

We expect the rivers to remain high throughout Friday with further rainfall expected from Friday evening. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Camel, River Allen, Bodmin Town Leat, River Valency

items.message:

Widespread rainfall totals of 20-30 mm are expected. Intense rain may result in totals of up 50 mm, increasing to 70mm over high ground. Urban areas may respond the quickest to this rainfall. Deep surface water and flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers is expected from around 8pm on Thursday. Flood warnings may be issued for some locations.

items.description: Ullswater and River Eamont at Pooley Bridge, Ullswater Steamer Pier to B5320 Bridge
items.message: River and Lake levels remain high at the Pooley Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is possible. Flooding is expected to affect properties on the B5320 between Dunmallard Hill and the River Eamont, including the Steamer Pier. We expect levels to remain high today 29/10/21, with some further rain forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation and our staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying roads and footpaths near the lake and rivers. This message will be updated this afternoon by 16:00, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible early on Friday morning. 
Heavy rainfall is falling over north Devon. This has meant that the rivers in the North Dartmoor area are now rising and there will be bankfull conditions with some localised riverside field flooding from around 8am.   
Further rain is forecast from Friday evening into Saturday morning. This will cause river levels to rise again with further flooding expected in the area.  
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible from 5am on Friday morning onwards.

Further rainfall is forecast to fall in the Lower Taw area which will cause water levels in the River Umberleigh to rise.

Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised riverside field flooding.

Further rainfall is expected from Friday evening into Saturday morning. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight Thursday in to Friday.

Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Exmoor Rivers area. This has meant that the Rivers Barle, Lyn, Mole, Bray and upper River Exe are now rising. 

The main areas of concern are Simonsbath, Brushford, Withypool and Dulverton, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from around 8:00pm on Thursday. 

We expect rivers to remain high throughout the night in to Friday though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not currently expected to be issued.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
We have seen a limited response in the rivers at the top of the catchment from last nights rain. The rain is clearing during today, 29/10/21, however we could see some showers throughout the day and further rain tomorrow morning, 30/10/21.
River levels at the top of the catchment have started to fall slowly but remain higher than normal. Saturdays rain could see limited response with levels being similar to those experienced last night.

The flood alert for the Upper River Wharfe is no longer in force. Rainfall totals came in lower than was forecast on Thursday 28th October and river levels did not rise as high as expected. Further rain is expected today, Friday 29th October, and over the weekend. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will re-issue the flood alert if it is required. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

River levels are rising at the Donyatt and Ashford Mill river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tonight, 28/10/21, and tomorrow, 29/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend.  We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Friday, 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone

items.message: River levels are rising at the Bishops Hull river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tonight, 28/10/21 and tomorrow, 29/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect roads around Hillfarrance, Bradford on Tone, Lane End Road at Ham and the Creech St Michael to Henlade road. Bradford on Tone ringbanks will be bankfull.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend.  We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Friday, 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are rising at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tonight, 28/10/21 and tomorrow, 29/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries.  Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Friday, 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the River Rye and tributaries is no longer in force. Rainfall totals came in lower than was forecast on Thursday 28th October and river levels did not rise as high as expected. Further rain is expected today, Friday 29th October, and over the weekend. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will re-issue the flood alert if it is required. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Tavy from Mary Tavy to Lopwell
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected during Thursday night and Friday morning. Take immediate action.
Heavy rain has fallen over the Tavy catchment with a further 20 mm of rain expected. This has caused the River Tavy to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising over the next 2-3 hours.
Properties and low lying areas around Stannary Bridge Road, Parkwood Road, Market Road, Dolvin Road, Abbey Walk, Pixon Lane at Tavistock will start to flood first from around 21:30 on Thursday. River levels are forecast to be at their highest around midnight and could remain high for several hours afterwards.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing, and roads could form flow routes. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 10am on Friday or earlier if the situation changes. Our staff are out in the area and will relay information and assist the emergency services and council.

We have seen a limited response in the rivers from last nights rain. The rain is clearing during the day. We could see some showers this evening and into Saturday morning. Frequent showers are likely to spread in from the north-west from late on Sunday and into Monday across the north of England and Wales.

We have seen a limited response in the rivers from last nights rain. The rain is clearing during the day. We could see some showers this evening and into Saturday morning. Frequent showers are likely to spread in from the north-west from late on Sunday and into Monday across the north of England and Wales.

items.description: River Lew at Gribbleford Bridge and Hatherleigh
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected overnight Thursday in to Friday.
Heavy rain falling in the Upper Torridge area will continue throughout this evening in to Friday. This is causing the River Lew to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising through the night.
Properties and low lying areas around the Riverside Kennels and roads at Passaford will start to flood first from around 9:30pm. 
If river levels continue to rise, properties around Gribbleford Bridge and at Hatherleigh - including the Fire Station, Petrol Station, Public House, lower end of Bridge Street and the A3072 and A386 - may be affected.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: Barnstaple, Braunton, Ilfracombe and Combe Martin area

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Caen, Bradiford Water, River Yeo

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight Thursday in to Friday.
Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the North Devon area. This has meant that the Rivers Caen, Bradiford Water and Yeo and coastal streams from Braunton to Combe Martin are now rising. 
The main areas of concern are Barnstaple, Braunton, Ilfracombe and Combe Martin, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers from around 10:30pm on Thursday. 
We expect rivers to remain high throughout the night and flood warnings may need to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Friday or earlier if the situation changes.

Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.

We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the night and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.message:

Properties and low lying areas around Coypool Road and Park and Ride, Marsh Close and Marsh Mills Retail Park will start to flood first. River levels are forecast to be at their highest around midnight and the early hours of Friday morning.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing, and roads could form flow routes. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 10am on Friday or earlier if the situation changes. floodArea.riverOrSea: River Torridge, River Waldon, River Lew

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight Thursday in to Friday.
Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Upper River Torridge area. This has meant that the Rivers Torridge, Waldon and Lew are now rising. 
The main areas of concern are Gribbleford Bridge, Passaford and Hatherleigh, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. 
We expect rivers to remain high throughout the night and in to Friday. Further flood warnings may also need to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Torridge (Lower) from Dolton to Bideford, including Taddiport and Weare Giffard
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected from around 11pm on Thursday continuing into Friday morning.

Heavy rain has been falling in the Torridge area throughout Thursday evening. This has caused the River Torridge to rise.
Properties and low lying areas in Taddiport (properties around Taddiport Bridge, Sewage Treatment Works and B3227) and Weare Giffard (riverside properties and roads), will start to flood first from around 11pm on Thursday evening. River levels will be at their highest between 1am and 5am.

Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.

We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon from Didworthy to Aveton Gifford
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected overnight Thursday in to Friday.
Heavy rain falling in the River Avon area will continue throughout Thursday night in to Friday. This is causing the River Avon to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising through the night.
Properties and low lying areas in South Brent, Avonwick, Brushford and Manor House near Diptford
Gara Bridge, Loddiswell  and Aveton Gifford will start to flood first from around 11:00pm on Thursday. 
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the night and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dart from Buckfastleigh to Totnes, including Staverton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected overnight Thursday in to Friday.
Heavy rain falling in the River Dart area will continue throughout the evening in to Friday. This is causing the River Dart to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising through the night.
Properties and low lying areas around Riverside and Netherton Cottages, Staverton Bridge and Town Mills areas of Staverton, will start to flood first from around 11:30pm on Thursday. River levels will be at their highest between midnight and 02:00am.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the night and this message will be updated as the situation changes. The Unigate Creamery should adjust penstocks on the Totnes Leat as required locally.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible in the earlier hours of the morning of Friday 29th October. Due to the persistent and heavy rainfall crossing the area during Thursday evening, and with up to 15mm of further rainfall expected throughout the night, deep surface water and flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers is possible. Catchments are saturated and rivers have responded quickly to tonights rain. 
Flood warnings may be issued for some locations.
The most persistent rain is expected to ease during Friday before further outbreaks of rain spread in from the west during the evening and into Saturday. River levels are likely to remain high during this time.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area ready to clear blockages as required. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Lyd from Sydenham to Lifton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected during the early hours of Friday morning. Take immediate action.
Heavy rain has fallen over the area with a further 15 mm of rain expected throughout the night. This has caused the River Lyd to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising over the next 2 hours.
Properties and low lying areas around Station Road Lifton will start to flood first. River levels are forecast to be at their highest around 02:00 and remain high throughout the early hours of Friday morning.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing, and roads could form flow routes. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by midday on Friday or earlier if the situation changes. Our staff are out in the area and will relay information and assist the emergency services and council.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected imminently. Take immediate action.
Heavy rain has fallen over the River Thrushel catchment with a further 20 mm of rain expected overnight. This has caused the River Thrushel to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising over the next 2-3 hours.
Properties near New Bridge including Bridge Cottage and low lying areas near the river will start to flood first. River levels are forecast to be at their highest in the early hours of Friday morning.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing, and roads could form flow routes. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 10am on Friday or earlier if the situation changes. Our staff are out in the area and will relay information and assist the emergency services and council.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected during the early hours of Friday morning. Take immediate action.
Heavy rain has fallen over the Tamar catchment with up to 15 mm of further rainfall expected throughout the night. This has caused the River Tamar to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising over the next 2-3 hours.
Properties and low lying areas around Bradstone Mill, Tutwell, Gunnislake, Morwellham Power Station and Cotehele will start to flood first. River levels are expected to remain high throughout the early hours of Friday morning.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing, and roads could form flow routes. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by midday on Friday or earlier if the situation changes. Our staff are out in the area and will relay information and assist the emergency services and council.

items.description: River Exe from Tiverton to Exeter, including Bickleigh
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected from around 4am Friday morning.
Heavy rain has been falling in the River Exe area throughout Thursday evening and into Friday morning. This has caused the River Exe to rise and the river will remain high for around two hours before levels begin to fall.
Properties and low lying areas in Bickleigh, Copenhagen, Traymill , Thorverton Mill, Nether Exe and Bampford Speke will start to flood first from around 4am on Friday. River levels will be at their highest between 4am and 6am.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the night and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Teign (Lower) from Chudleigh to Kingsteignton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on Friday morning.
Heavy rain has been falling in the Lower River Teign area throughout Thursday evening and into Friday morning. This has caused the River Teign to rise and the river will remain high for the next couple of hours before levels begin to fall later on Friday.
Properties and low lying areas around Ventiford Cottages and properties around Ventiford Bridge, School Cottages at Teigngrace, businesses at Teignbridge Level Crossing, Sandford Orleigh Farm and the Exeter Road will start to flood first from around 06:00am on Friday. River levels will be at their highest between 06:00am and 10:00am.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yarty from Yarcombe to Axminster
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Heavy rain falling in the area on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning has caused the River Yarty to rise.

Riverside property and highway flooding is expected. Minor roads and fords near to and across the river will be impassable. Stock in riverside fields without access to high ground are at risk.

Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.

We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on Friday morning.
Heavy rain has been falling in the River Clyst area throughout Thursday evening and into Friday morning. This has caused the River Clyst to rise and the river will remain high for the next couple of hours before levels begin to fall later on Friday.
There is likely to be deep road flooding in the Burrow, Broadclyst Bridge, Clyston Mill, Dymond's Farm and Sowton Barton areas and flooding to properties and farms between Clyst St. Mary and Topsham including Newcourt Barton and Cotts Farm. River levels will be at their highest between 06:30am and 10:00am.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible early on Friday morning.
Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Exe area. This has caused the River Exe to rise and there will be bankfull conditions with some localised riverside flooding. 
River levels will begin to fall during the day on Friday. However, further rainfall is forecast from Friday evening into Saturday morning. This will cause river levels to rise again and there may be further flooding in the area.  

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Creedy, River Yeo, Lapford Yeo, Little Dart

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Friday morning.

Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Mid Devon Area. This has meant that the rivers in the Mid Devon Area are now rising. River levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. 

River levels may begin to fall during the day on Friday. However, further rainfall is forecast from Friday evening into Saturday morning. This will cause river levels to rise again and there may be further flooding in the area.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hay-On-Wye river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding (of property) is imminent.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye 2.1m to 2.5m  today 29/10, Bredwardine 4.1m to 4.4m this afternoon 29/10, Belmont 4.1m to 4.5m this afternoon 29/10, Old Wye Bridge 3.7m to 4.0m this evening 29/10, Mordiford 3.8m to 4.2m this evening 29/10, Ross on Wye 3.0m to 3.5m Tomorrow 30/10  
 We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  this afternoon, 29/10/2021 by 14:00, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding (of property) is imminent.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland.   
 We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  this afternoon,this afternoon 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers in the Forest of Dean
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Parkend river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Friday 29/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Gloucester to Chepstow. Other locations that may be affected include Westbury and Lydney.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend and we expect river levels to remain high over the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
  
This message will be updated by 2pm today Friday 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for North Sea coast at Bridlington has now been issued. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of strong winds and high waves. The particular areas of concern are Bridlington South Pier between 12:30 and 16:30 and Bridlington Lifeboat Station between 11:30 and 15:30 on Friday 29th October. Please take care around exposed promenades and roads where spray may create hazardous conditions. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Onibury river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding (of property) is imminent.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include  Church Stretton and Ludlow. Predicted peaks:-  Onibury 1.6m to 1.8m this afternoon 29/10.
We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  this afternoon, 29/10/2021 by 14:00, or as the situation changes.
